prompt: Facts: On August 12, 1990, Ruchika Girhotra (14 years old), a promising tennis player, was allegedly molested by Shambhu Pratap Singh Rathore (S.P.S. Rathore), then Inspector General of Police (IGP), Haryana, and President of the Haryana Lawn Tennis Association (HLTA), in his office-cum-residence in Panchkula, Haryana.; Ruchika was accompanied by her friend Aradhana Prakash.; Ruchika and Aradhana reported the incident to their parents.; Ruchika's family decided to pursue legal action against Rathore.; Following the complaint, Ruchika was expelled from her school (Sacred Heart Convent School, Chandigarh) allegedly due to pressure exerted by Rathore (reason cited: non-payment of fees, disputed by family).; Systematic harassment allegedly followed against Ruchika's family and the Prakash family (Aradhana's parents, Madhu and Anand Prakash).; Ruchika's brother, Ashu Girhotra, faced multiple allegedly false criminal cases (including theft, auto theft) filed by the Haryana Police between 1990 and 1993, resulting in his arrest and alleged torture.; An inquiry conducted by DGP R.R. Singh in 1990 indicted Rathore, but no immediate formal action (FIR) was taken.; On December 28, 1993, Ruchika Girhotra consumed poison.; Ruchika died on December 29, 1993.; The suicide was linked by her family and supporters to the trauma of the molestation and the subsequent persistent harassment, particularly the targeting of her brother Ashu.; A Public Interest Litigation (PIL) was filed by the Prakash family in the Punjab and Haryana High Court.; The High Court transferred the investigation to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) in 2000.; CBI filed charges against Rathore, initially including Section 306 IPC (Abetment of suicide).; Trial commenced, charges were later framed primarily under Section 354 IPC (Molestation). Charges under Section 306 IPC were dropped by the trial court.; On December 21, 2009, the CBI Special Court in Chandigarh convicted S.P.S. Rathore under Section 354 IPC and sentenced him to 6 months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000.; On May 25, 2010, the Chandigarh Sessions Court upheld the conviction and enhanced the sentence to 18 months (1.5 years) rigorous imprisonment.; Rathore appealed to the Punjab and Haryana High Court, which upheld the conviction but granted bail.; The Supreme Court of India heard appeals from both Rathore (against conviction/sentence) and CBI/Prakash family (seeking conviction under Section 306 IPC and enhancement/confirmation of sentence).; On September 23, 2016, the Supreme Court upheld Rathore's conviction under Section 354 IPC but reduced the sentence to the period already undergone (around 6 months), citing his advanced age and the protracted nature of the litigation. | IPC: Section 354 (Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty) - Convicted, Section 306 (Abetment of suicide) - Charged by CBI, dropped by Trial Court, appeal for inclusion dismissed by SC, Section 120B (Criminal Conspiracy) - Discussed in relation to harassment, but no specific conviction, Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) - Potentially relevant to harassment campaign, but primary focus was Rathore's individual act for 354, Section 193 (Punishment for false evidence) - Discussed regarding false cases against Ashu, but no direct charge against Rathore pursued to conviction, Section 201 (Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender) - Potentially relevant to alleged cover-ups/manipulation of inquiries, Section 342 (Punishment for wrongful confinement) - Relevant to Ashu's alleged illegal detentions
